syllabus:
讓學生在了解、接觸文獻的同時，具備整合資料、運用資料的能力。

並透過這門課程，讓學生更加了解臺灣文獻中的重要人物與事蹟。

The purpose of this course is to nurture an understanding of the major intellectual debates, standard works, and primary source materials concerning the topics and themes that are significant to the historical narrative, and narrative history of contemporary Taiwan society. The bilingual textbook _The Concise History of Taiwan, Chinese-English Bilingual Edition_戴寶村著 《簡明臺灣史》will serve as overview guideline, but its general content will be illustrated with supplementary readings. In the discussion of the supplementary readings, specific attention will be paid to the bibliographic references, and to the introduction of primary and seminal source materials. The exam will be a reading of a short story and students will write a brief essay that situates the story in its historical/ contemporary context based on the readings and text materials provided throughout the course.

**週**11 **11****月** **26****日** **Taiwan seen from the perspective as an Immigrant Society** : 

**Taiwan in the 18th century and 19th Century**

General reading _The Concise History of Taiwan, Chinese-English Bilingual Edition_ (chapter 2),

pp. 75-97.

Supplementary readings for this class will highlight topics in the discussion of the historical-geography,

visual arts, architecture and socio-economic history. Attention will be paid to the transition from

Ming to Manchu-Qing, the opening of Taiwan to the West from the mid-19th century onwards

and the cultural encounter between the differing ethnic groups according to their migration

patterns since the 17th century.

pp. 98-116. Supplementary readings for this class feature the Taiwan ethnicity and identity issue,

and its representation in Taiwanese literature. Attention will be paid to **an introduction of writers**

**and their literary works.**

A selection of chapters from the following edited volumes:

Mark Mancall, (ed.) _Formosa Today_, New York: Frederick A. Praeger, 1964.

reprint, 1994.

Murray A. Rubinstein (ed.) _The Other Taiwan, 1945 to the present,_ New York: Sharpe, 1994.

Murray A. Rubinstein (ed.) _Taiwan. A New History,_ New York: Sharpe, 1999.

**Introduction of Taiwanese Literature: writers, literary works, sources and databases.**

**週**13  **12****月** **10****日**  Understanding Taiwan as a postwar/colonial society

General reading _The Concise History of Taiwan, Chinese-English Bilingual Edition_ (chapter 4),

pp. 130-158. The focus is debates regarding the interpretation of major events and the narrativization

of historical personalities in Taiwan history. Supplementary readings will provide overview articles

on Taiwan historiography.

Invited lecture: Chang Lung-chih (TBC) 

**週**14  **12****月** **17****日**  Taiwan since martial law : society, culture, and media

General reading _The Concise History of Taiwan, Chinese-English Bilingual Edition_ (chapter 4),

Supplementary readings will focus on topics in Taiwan media research and Taiwan cinema

(film studies).
